page.title: 08Welbeck Pit in the 1970/80s
page.content: The loss of man-power in the 1960s led to the introduction of a successful incentive scheme,mainly pushed through by Nottinghamshire miners. By 1979 the pits overproducing and stock piles grew,at Welbeck Colliery in particular,as they had plenty of room to store the excess coal.This led to the strike of 1984 having relatively little effect on the power output of the country since existing stocks were ample to "outlast" the strike. When the 1984 strike started there were 480 men on strike out of Welbeck's workforce of 1265,but by March 1985 it had dropped down to 80 hardened strikers.The area was visited regularly by pickets from neighbouring areas and there was much ill-feeling in Meden Vale,whose inhabitants quote the strike as the area's worst event.
